Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re well. Haven’t heard from you in a while.” I glanced at the clock—Saturday, 9:15 a.m. I’d meant to call her last night, but work had run late. I typed a quick reply, “All good, just busy. Will call soon!” and hit send, guilt prickling at my conscience. 

Just then, my calendar pinged: a reminder for the advocacy team’s weekly meeting at 9:30. I was expected to be there, on time, every week—no excuses. My supervisor had stressed the importance of punctuality, especially with court sessions coming up. I stared at my phone, torn. If I called Mom now, I’d be late for the meeting. If I waited, I’d be letting her down again. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my parents’ need for connection, my clients’ need for my presence. My thumb hovered over the call button, heart pounding, as I tried to decide which expectation to meet first.
